20191: Devastation.author: sarroth
20191: Devastation.text_parsed:
@Ace: Actually, plainswalkers like Zodiac Rooster won't survive, given that they're creatures :P

In seriousness, I like this better than Obliterate, even if it does less. Mostly because this can be countered, so I leave my opponents an opportunity to answer what will likely be a game-deciding play if it goes unanswered, given that I've likely set myself up with something like Ghostway to start off strong after the "reset." Obliterate only gives them a response if they run some more obscure and more expensive counters like Mindbreak Trap, and as such will be more likely to be an "oops, I win" card. I would rather have my opponents stop me from winning than hate having played because they felt they had no chance at all.

20194: Last Chance.author: Gelzo
20194: Last Chance.text_parsed:
The difference between this and Final Fortune is that this is a Sorcery whereas the other is an instant.

I imagine that it won't normally make a difference, since you'd normally want to cast in during your turn, but you could cast Final Fortune in response to things.

Of course, that doesn't necessarily make it better in every deck, since there are cards like Magnivore that go better with sorceries.

Warrior's Oath, however, is exactly the same except for the name.

I guess with this, that, and Final Fortune, you could have basically 12 of the same card in your deck, but I'm not sure what kind of deck would be able to make that work.

20194: Last Chance.author: legendary_orp
20194: Last Chance.text_parsed: @PEVE_O: This wouldn't combo with Hive Mind. You cast this spell, before it resolves, they get a copy and it resolves. Then your version resolves. But extra turns are taken in the reverse order that the effects resolved in. Meaning you would take your extra turn before theirs, and since you're playing Hive Mind, probably don't have the board state to win the game in that turn.

20197: Hulking Ogre.author: The-Earth-Dragon
20197: Hulking Ogre.text_parsed:
@silverware: The problem Wizards has these days is that most of the core sets are very complex and so it is harder to teach people how to play magic unless they really want to learn. Having sets around that bring the complexity of the game down is good in theory, but when your friends who are established are playing with the complex cards, it defeats the purpose.

Also, these sets were made after Urza's and before Mirrodin, a time where the overall power level of cards was a little lower. With the recent power hike we've had again, of course all those cards look terrible. It's inevitable that the only thing creative developers will think of to field cards people want to play is make everything stronger then their old cards. Look at some of the spoiled cards for Avacyn Restored. There are cards that people use semi-regularly that are about to be replaced by cards that do everything they do plus something else at no additional cost. Does stuff like have to happen....maybe not. But will it happen......without a doubt.

Acidic Slime is a useful creature, but 5 mana is a lot for some formats, and other 4 mana options like Avalanche Riders have an ability that is a drawback for a lot of decks (Echo), except for Living End or Momentary Blink decks. This is goblin tribal, which matters for Goblin Lackey and Warren Instigator, and is absolutely cruel in a Heartless Summonning deck with Havengul Lich.

20234: Monstrous Growth.author: WraithBalor
20234: Monstrous Growth.text_parsed: I'm stumped and have a question here. I have 4 copies of this card. One is from the Portal set, and one is Starter 2000. The other 2 are where I'm running in to a problem. They have the squirrel picture, which means they must be from Starter 1999, Starter 2000, or Portal Second Age. They have a black line separating the text, which rules out 2000. They also have a star for the edition, and the artists name centered, which should mean they're 1999. However, they have a white border like 2000, instead of the black border it shows for 1999. Thoughts anyone? Did I find some misprints? Fluke copies? Or is the border being both colors in one printing common? And if it makes them any different, does it change the price on them at all? Thanks!
20234: Monstrous Growth.text_posted: I'm stumped and have a question here. I have 4 copies of this card. One is from the Portal set, and one is Starter 2000. However, they have a [b]white[/b] border like 2000, instead of the black border it shows for 1999. Thoughts anyone? Did I find some misprints? Fluke copies? Or is the border being both colors in one printing common? And if it makes them any different, does it change the price on them at all? Thanks!

20359: Grim Tutor.author: Pariah_Press
20359: Grim Tutor.text_parsed: I don't think that it's expensive because it's unrestricted. I haven't seen a competitive deck that uses more than one of these. Once you have Demonic Tutor, Vampiric Tutor, and Imperial Seal in your deck, this can be tutor #4, if you're playing Dark Rituals in your deck. The reason it's expensive is because it's extremely rare (hardly anyone bought Starter boosters in any quantity) and it's playable in Vintage combo decks.
20359: Grim Tutor.text_posted: I don't think that it's expensive because it's unrestricted.  I haven't seen a competitive deck that uses more than one of these. 20385: Hollow Dogs.author: elkram
20385: Hollow Dogs.text_parsed:
I'm just gonna put this here, just because I want to make sure I never forget this card. This card got me into magic.

Of all the cards, of all the art work, this was the one that first got me to actually learn what Magic was. Look at the art. I mean look at it. For an 8 year old boy, seeing this card on a table and just looking at it. It was so cool. The only other card game I knew was Pokemon, but this looked like it came straight out of those Goosebumps books and that was just awesome. I knew I wanted to play this game, or at least get the cards because the art was so damn awesome.

Now, unfortunately I didn't stick with it, but when I went to a new school a few years later, seeing the kids playing magic during indoor recess, I instantly remembered my old cards, and especially this guy. Well, I knew, if there was ever a chance, I wanted to play magic during indoor recess. I did, eventually. And even got to play some during outdoor recess. But then middle school came and I couldn't bother to be associated with anything seen as "nerdy" or "geeky" so I shunned magic. For 6 years, I didn't play magic. But once I got over that phase of not doing "nerdy" or "geeky" things, I started playing again with my friends who pushed me back into it. And one of the few cards I had in my mind was this guy.

Sure he isn't the best card ever, and sure his artwork doesn't compare to others, but this card got me into magic, and I will never forget it. In fact, I may get a copy, since I lost mine long ago, and I would proudly show it off on the first sheet of my collection for all people to see when they trade with me.

20400: Angelic Blessing.author: Infini-
20400: Angelic Blessing.text_parsed:
This is a pretty bad pump. It's a glorified Giant Growth costing 2 mana more. Sure it does grant you flying, so your creature has a chance to go through for some damage, but it's a sorcery so surprising your opponent and potentially taking out a bigger creature is out of the window.

Play Giant Growth and it's kin if you need a good pump, try something like Distortion Strike if you care about your creatures going through unblocked. And if you really want to spend 3 mana in white just play another creature.

1/5

20400: Angelic Blessing.author: WokeUpDead
20400: Angelic Blessing.text_parsed:
1. It's Portal! There -weren't- any instants to fool around with, and only cards like Mystic Denial and Extinguish could've touched this. I imagine that this was pretty darned strong for the time.

2. Say we lived in a non-Portal world. This still turns your mana dorks into 4/4 fliers, forcing your opponent to think about, "Geez, do I want the 2-for-1 or is his other threat on the board still just going to murder me?"

3.5 in the weird land known as Portal, 2.5 as a card I think would be reasonable to see again for a draft format one of these days.

21028: Storm Crow.author: Shadoflaam
21028: Storm Crow.text_parsed:
I made a format today. I called it A Feast for Crows.
The Power 9, Jace, the Mind Sculptor and Tolarian Academy are unrestricted, but only 4 of one Mox color is allowed per deck (e.g. 4 Mox Sapphire but no Jet, Ruby, Emerald or Pearl). The only creatures allowed are 4 of these, 2 Mindless Null OR Mogg Jailer, and one Demon of Death's Gate. EVERY OTHER NONBASIC CARD IS BANNED.
Quite honestly it is the most fun format ever.

21049: Piracy.author: C5r1a5z0y
21049: Piracy.text_parsed:
Unfortunately there probably isn't a way to fix this without a power-level errata. Seems like it would be better to print a new card instead, something like:
Until end of turn, you may force opponents to tap lands they control for mana.
Until end of turn, you may use mana in opponents' mana pools to cast spells.

That gets around them tapping out (since you could then access the mana), and shouldn't cause collisions, since the player with priority during putting a spell/ability on the stack (i.e. paying for something) is the only one who can use mana from a pool.
21049: Piracy.text_posted:
Unfortunately there probably isn't a way to fix this without a power-level errata.  Seems like it would be better to print a new card instead, something like:

That gets around them tapping out (since you could then access the mana), and shouldn't cause collisions, since the player with priority during putting a spell/ability on the stack (i.e. paying for something) is the only one who can use mana from a pool.

21057: Devoted Hero.author: voidweaver
21057: Devoted Hero.text_parsed:
I remember playing this card in a pretty good white weenie deck in high school. It ran Savannah lions, mother of runes, soul warden and many far better one-drops than this. But devoted hero, he didn't let it get him down that he was way outclassed by every other card in the deck! He kept bravely fighting no matter the odds. While the lions or wardens or other cards at all considered any real threat would be blocked and taken down, devoted hero was there to punch through the lines and go head-to-head with the opposing planeswalker. I once saw him take down a whole pack of tundra wolves.

I don't know what happened to him after that, but I'll never forget devoted hero. Wouldn't use him in a deck, but won't forget him.
21057: Devoted Hero.text_posted:
I remember playing this card in a pretty good white weenie deck in high school.  It ran [autocard]Savannah lions[/autocard], [autocard]mother of runes[/autocard], [autocard]soul warden[/autocard] and many far better one-drops than this.  But devoted hero, he didn't let it get him down that he was way outclassed by every other card in the deck!  He kept bravely fighting no matter the odds.  While the lions or wardens or other cards at all considered any real threat would be blocked and taken down, devoted hero was there to punch through the lines and go head-to-head with the opposing planeswalker.  I once saw him take down a whole pack of [autocard]tundra wolves[/autocard].

I don't know what happened to him after that, but I'll never forget devoted hero.  Wouldn't use him in a deck, but won't forget him.

21065: Mons's Goblin Raiders.author: Ladnarud
21065: Mons's Goblin Raiders.text_parsed:
The true power of this card is in its ability to be placed in the graveyard after it is destroyed OR after it has its toughness reach 0. This opens up a world of possibilities, especially for red/black decks. Plus, it has no rules text and no special abilities, which in turn can't be used to its disadvantage by manipulative blue spells.

Also, think about it... you're paying for one power AND toughness, which is a bargain at any mana cost.

Amazing card with lots of utility and potential.

0.5/5

21066: Goblin Hero.author: Ladnarud
21066: Goblin Hero.text_parsed:
Two generic mana for a 2/2 creature, and one extra red mana for the generous privilege of being a 'Goblin'-type creature. Having no rules text or special abilities also makes him a very clever, underestimated threat to opponents, allowing him to deal damage unhindered.

Also, being a creature of the 'Goblin' subtype allows him to untap for FREE during his controller's untap step.

Very powerful and underestimated card.

0.5/5

21066: Goblin Hero.author: SleetFox
21066: Goblin Hero.text_parsed:
I have this very version of this card. I store my cards alphabetically by color, with the rares, timeshifts and mythic rares stored separately in card sleeves.

I was looking through my reds for a good card to add to my burn deck after realizing that I accidentally managed to have 5 of a card in it, and I realized that I actually managed to file this as if it weren't rare. I just thought it was amusing because this is the lamest rare ever. Even stuff like One With Nothing and Mudhole get a pass because they have unusual effects that make you think about ways to use them. But this... This is just sad.

At first I thought "maybe this is a rare because at the time this was the biggest goblin." But no. Enslaved Scout was the same thing with an added ability. In Alliances. As a common. I understand that this card is older than Alliances, but it wasn't a rare until three years after.
21066: Goblin Hero.text_posted:
I have this very version of this card.  I store my cards alphabetically by color, with the rares, timeshifts and mythic rares stored separately in card sleeves.

I was looking through my reds for a good card to add to my burn deck after realizing that I accidentally managed to have 5 of a card in it, and I realized that I actually managed to file this as if it weren't rare.  I just thought it was amusing because this is the [i]lamest rare ever[/i].  Even stuff like [autocard]One With Nothing[/autocard] and [autocard]Mudhole[/autocard] get a pass because they have unusual effects that make you think about ways to use them.  But this... This is just sad.

At first I thought "maybe this is a rare because at the time this was the biggest goblin."   But no.  [autocard]Enslaved Scout[/autocard] was the same thing with an added ability.  In Alliances.  As a common.  I understand that this card is older than Alliances, but it wasn't a rare until three years after.

21069: Ransack.author: cha0sc0w
21069: Ransack.text_parsed:
Milling 5 isn't even close to rearranging 5. The "fateseal 5 " effect is amazingly powerful compared to milling 5. Milling means they won't draw those cards, and they have access to them in the graveyard. You are also milling them to a random next card on top and you are milling 5 random cards in most cases which overall gets rid of as many threats as dead cards. Milling almost never truly stops your opponent from doing something unless through pure luck, and it can just as easily mill to the point that lets them do what you were trying to stop them from doing.

ex: Your opponent needs a land for fireball to kill you, if you mill 5, you don't know what is on top, you could mill them 5 lands and their top card is too expensive and useless and you win the game. Or you could mill 5 non-lands and they get a land on top and they win the game. While with this card you know what they have on top and you can almost guarantee they don't get a land drop.

Fateseal however hopefully won't be reprinted due to it's complete dominating power, it is part of one of the many reasons JTMS was absolutely broken. By fixing the opponents top-deck, you are guaranteeing that they won't have anything to deal with your threats and that they will have no threats of their own, you can mana screw them in either way or give them all their high cost creatures they can't play. You can tell when their threat is coming if or when you have some way to deal with it.

In most formats saying "you are just going to draw lands for the next three turns" is absolutely brutal and can win you the game. Sadly, this is too expensive. It needs instant, to cost less, or to cantrip or something to make it usable in a legacy or modern environment.

This is meant to provide a little early-to-mid game beef in a deck that includes Green but is not predominantly Green. In such a context, this card can be decent.

Strangely, I find that if I start sliding Green into a deck to provide 'Green support', I tend to convert the deck into a Green deck that is supported by the other color(s). Green's mana ramp is pretty powerful, but it usually calls for {G} production at the earliest opportunity, rather than secondarily.

21785: Trained Orgg.author: jsttu
21785: Trained Orgg.text_parsed:
Abysmal. If you use this card and have been playing magic for more than a month you should be shot. Vanilla cards aren't very good normally unless they are very aggressively costed, which this guy is not. There are so many cards better than this guy that are cheap and affordable that there really is no excuse to playing him unless you don't have enough cards for a deck otherwise.

Deus of Calamity, just about any dragon, and even his cousin Butcher Orgg are strictly better than him, although the latter still isn't very good. Heck, if you are willing to pay an additional mana you could play Akroma, Angel of Fury, who is just amazing.

21785: Trained Orgg.author: Radagast
21785: Trained Orgg.text_parsed:
What angers me the most about this card and it's laughable blue cousin is that they knew that these things were terrible when printed, and yet made them anyway. While we are all used to creatures being effectively priced these days, there was a time in Magic's distant past where creatures - at least larger ones - were becoming LESS effective than what the game started with. Good cards like Shivan Dragon, Phantom Monster, and so on were removed to make way for underpowered drek like this. It's no wonder that so few creatures were tournament worthy back then, and most of them were aggressively costed smaller ones since the larger creature slots were being filled up with this nonsense.

A bad card and a relic from a time when the game was going backwards.
21785: Trained Orgg.text_posted:
What angers me the most about this card and it's laughable blue cousin is that they knew that these things were terrible when printed, and yet made them anyway. While we are all used to creatures being effectively priced these days, there was a time in Magic's distant past where creatures - at least larger ones - were becoming LESS effective than what the game started with. Good cards like Shivan Dragon, Phantom Monster, and so on were removed to make way for underpowered drek like this. It's no wonder that so few creatures were tournament worthy back then, and most of them were aggressively costed smaller ones since the larger creature slots were being filled up with this nonsense.

A bad card and a relic from a time when the game was going backwards.

21785: Trained Orgg.author: Equinox523
21785: Trained Orgg.text_parsed:
Presenting a comprehensive list of the strongest monored vanilla creatures to date. Note that this list does not include "virtual vanillas" like Raging Goblin or Kird Ape.

1 Mana:
Mons's Goblin Raiders, 1/1
Dwarven Trader, 1/1

2 Mana:
Goblin Bully, 2/1
Goblin Piker, 2/1
Independent Troops, 2/1

3 Mana:
Regathan Firecat, 4/1
Goblin Cavaliers, 3/2
Goblin Roughrider, 3/2
Balduvian Barbarians, 3/2
Riot Devils, 2/3
Hurloon Minotaur, 2/3

4 Mana:
Cobblebrute, 5/2
Cyclops of One-Eyed Pass, 5/2
Lowland Giant, 4/3
Ogre Resister, 4/3
Shatterskull Giant, 4/3
Borderland Minotaur, 4/3
Highland Giant, 3/4

5 Mana:
Raging Poltergeist, 6/1
Scoria Elemental, 6/1
Fire Elemental, 5/4
Earth Elemental, 4/5

6 Mana:
Axegrinder Giant, 6/4
Flameborn Viron, 6/4

7 Mana:
Trained Orgg

It's actually the only monored vanilla 7-drop, surprisingly, thereby making it the best by default. However, it's woefully underpowered and underwhelming. The worst thing about this is that it's not even as evocative as Shivan Dragon, which is flavorful and feels powerful when it hits the table. This doesn't inspire that kind of awe, and for obvious reasons has not come back in recent times.
